Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Does the concept of a/an Orbit need to be defined for a definition of a/an Alternating Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Alternating Group does not inherently require the concept of an Orbit. The Alternating Group, as defined, is a specific subset of the symmetric group consisting of all even permutations of a set. This definition is based on the properties of permutations and their signs, and does not involve the action of the group on a set, which is central to the concept of an Orbit. An Orbit involves the action of a group on a set and describes the set of elements that can be reached from a given element by the action of any group element. Since the definition of the Alternating Group is self-contained with respect to the properties of permutations and does not require considering group actions on sets, the concept of an Orbit is not necessary for defining or understanding an Alternating Group.
